content.webTitle: Deafheaven: New Bermuda review – cinematic mainstream-friendly metal

fields.headline: Deafheaven: New Bermuda review – cinematic mainstream-friendly metal
fields.bodyText: Deafheaven’s breakout moment came with the release of Sunbather, the group’s death-metal LP that saw them cross over and become, like Liturgy before them, a Pitchfork-approved version of the genre. Alongside the screamed vocals of George Clarke and double bass drumming of Daniel Tracy, came swatches of post-rock and shoegaze’s atmospheric chords from songwriter/guitarist Kerry McCoy. New Bermuda sees them follow that up by pushing things even further. Brought to the Water starts with industrial drones and church bells, Luna mixes thrash with cinematic breakdowns and Gifts for the Earth is more motorik than metal. That hybrid quality is what makes the band anathema to some metal fans – a position that hasn’t been helped by claims guitarist Kerry McCoy used homophobic language on Twitter – but this is a band moving beyond one simple characterisation. While claims they’ve got a “pop-like accessibility” feel overstated, those who like the loud bits of Mogwai and the more melodic moments of Dillinger Escape Plan will have found the metal band for them.
